When copper(II) sulfate is dissolved in hot water, it forms a blue solution due to the formation of hydrated copper(II) sulfate, which has a characteristic blue color. In this reaction, heat is used to dissolve the copper(II) sulfate, and once the dissolving process is complete, the flame is turned off and the beaker is moved to cool. This helps to prevent further reaction and ensure that the solution remains stable.
